children.name: assert
children.doc:
Methods for throwing or logging on failed assertions,
useful for unit testing.

An implementation of the CommonJS Unit Testing 1.0
Specification's `assert` module.
http://wiki.commonjs.org/wiki/Unit_Testing/1.0

returns.doc: an error, that may contain backtrace information on Rhino and V8.

children.name: toString

returns.doc: a representation of the error.

children.doc: WARNING: This method is not specified.

children.name: toSource

returns.doc: an evaluable representation of the error.

children.doc: WARNING: This method is not specified.

children.name: fail
children.doc: WARNING: This method is not specified.

children.name: pass
children.doc:
Called by the test runner when a test passes.

This method is inteded to be overridden by inheritors,
particularly loggers.  The base implementation is a
no-op.

WARNING: This method is not specified.

children.name: error
children.doc:
Called by the test runner when a test errors out.

This method is inteded to be overridden by inheritors,
particularly loggers.  The base implementation is a
no-op.

WARNING: This method is not specified.

children.name: section

returns.doc: this

children.doc:
Called by the test runner when a test errors begins
a new section of tests and is expected to return an
object suitable for sending log messages like "pass",
"error", "fail", and "section".

This method is inteded to be overridden by inheritors,
particularly loggers.  The base implementation is a
no-op.

WARNING: This method is not specified.

throws.doc: an error with the given message if value is not truthy
an error with the given message if the actual and expected values are not loosely equal (`!=`).
an error with the given message if the actual and expected values are loosely equal (`==`).
an error with the given message if the actual and expected values are not deeply equivalent, for their transitive properties.
an error with the given message if the actual and expected values are deeply equivalent, for their transitive properties.
an error with the given message if the actual and expected values are not strictly equal (`!==`).
an error with the given message if the actual and expected values are strictly equal (`===`).

params.name: Error
params.doc: optional, shifts left by one positional argument if `message` is omitted, or `Error` by default.  @throws {AssertionError} calls the given block and throw an error with the given message if the block does not throw an error of the given type.

children.name: Assert

params.name: log
params.doc: an object, inherited from the assert module itself, that will send messages to the given log object instead of throwing exceptions.

returns.doc: an object inheriting prototypically from the `assert` module itself, with `pass`, `fail`, `error`, and `section` overridden to forward messages to the given `Log` object.

children.doc:
Constructs a logging `assert` object.
WARNING: This method is not specified.

children.name: test
children.doc:
Facilities for running and logging unit test modules.

An implementation and extension of the CommonJS Unit
Testing 1.0 Specification's `test` module.
http://wiki.commonjs.org/wiki/Unit_Testing/1.0

children.name: parser
children.doc:
an arguments parser from the `narwhal/args`
module for parsing command line arguments.

    TERM= js -m test --help

    Usage: test.js TEST [OPTIONS]
     --no-color
     --loop
     --show-stack-traces
     --show-passes
     -q --quiet
     -h --help: displays usage information (final option)

children.name: run

params.name: test
params.type: Test ~ {test*: Function || This, setup?: Function, teardown?: Function}
params.doc: * a test object including `test*` functions or nested test * objects.

params.name: log
params.doc: a log object for reporting test results.

returns.doc: 0 if all tests pass.

children.doc:
Runs and reports the results of a unit test or a tree of
unit tests.

children.name: Log
errors: Could not recognize `@param` "stream: a synchronous IO stream as implemented by `narwhal/io`."
children.doc:
A stream logger for test results, suitable for running
command line unit tests.

children.name: stream
children.doc:
a section object with an appropriate
level of indentation

children.name: report
children.doc:
Prints final tallies of passed, failed, and errored
tests.

children.name: print
children.doc:
A proxy for printing to the associated stream, where
each print is indented appropriately for the depth
of the section.

returns.doc: section a new section.
a new assertion logger that reports to this log.

children.name: Section

params.name: indent
params.doc: a prefix for each line printed with the `print` method.

children.doc:
Section adapters wrap any object with a print
method such that every line is indented.

children.name: Binary
children.doc: A base type for `ByteString` and `ByteArray`.

children.name: narwhal/buffer
children.doc: Provides a binary Buffer type.

children.name: copy

throws.doc: an Error if the source or target ranges are out of their respective bounds.

returns.doc: this

children.doc: (targetStop is targetStart + (stop - stop))

children.name: copyFrom

throws.doc: an Error if the source or target ranges are out of their respective bounds.

returns.doc: this

children.doc: (sourceStop is sourceStart + (stop - start))

returns.doc: that views a part of this buffer's allocated bytes, such that changes to either are reflected in the other..
that contains a copy of a part of this buffer's allocated bytes, such that changes to this buffer and the new buffer are isolated.
the crc32 hash for a string as an integer.

children.name: deprecated
children.doc:
Prints a deprecation warning to standard output, with
terminal colors if possible.

children.name: narwhal/encodings
children.doc: Provides character set encoders, decoders, and transcoders.

children.name: Transcoder
children.doc:
An object that maintains the state for streaming bytes
encoded in a source character set to a target character
set, providing a {@link transcode} method for transcoding
chunks of data from a source buffer to a target buffer.

returns.doc: state

children.name: DecoderReader
children.doc:
An input stream decorator that transforms a byte stream
into a character stream with the given character set.

- reads bytes
- returns character

children.name: EncoderWriter
children.doc:
- accepts characters
- writes bytes

children.name: narwhal/event-loop-hook
children.doc:
This module is exclusively for the purpose of arranging
for an "event-loop-engine" to begin dispatching events
when the initial thread of execution runs to its
completion.

`narwhal/narwhal.js` checks whether this module has been
loaded after the main module returns and calls the
"emit" method.  No module is intended to call "emit"
manually.

children.name: when

returns.doc: undefined

children.doc:
Arrange for an observer function to be called after the
"main" module returns.

children.name: emit
children.doc:
This method, called by the engine after the "main" module
returns, invokes all of the observers (intended to be a
single event loop runner registered by an
"event-loop-engine") in the order they were requested.

children.name: setEventLoop

throws.doc: Error if an event loop has already been configured.

children.doc:
Configures the system to use a particular event loop
implementation.  The event loop must support the event
loop API:

* `setTimeout`
* `clearTimeout`
* `setInterval`
* `clearInterval`
* `enqueue` is optional; if it is not provided, the
  event-loop module will provide one in terms of
  setTimeout(task, 0).

children.name: getEventLoop
children.doc:
Returns an event loop implementation.  If no event loop
has been configured, configures the "event-loop-engine"
module as the default implementation.  After this method
has been called, the event loop cannot be changed.
The "event-loop" module itself uses this method the first
time it is required.

children.name: enqueue
children.doc: Performs a task in a future turn of the event loop.

children.name: setTimeout

returns.doc: an opaque token, usable by `clearTimeout` to abort the timeout.

children.doc: Performs a task once, later.

children.name: clearTimeout

params.name: token
params.doc: an opaque token, as returned by `setTimeout`

children.doc: Aborts a timeout.

children.name: setInterval

params.name: period
params.doc: a delay and interval in miliseconds.

returns.doc: an opaque token, usable by `clearInterval` to abort further events.

children.doc:
Performs a task repeatedly, after the given
delay and subsequently on the same period.

children.name: clearInterval

params.name: token
params.doc: an opaque token, as returned by `setInterval`

children.doc: Aborts an interval timer.

children.name: hasPendingEvents

returns.doc: whether there may be further events.

children.doc:
WARNING: The existence of this method is not
guaranteed on all engines.

children.name: processNextEvent
children.doc:
WARNING: The existence of this method is not
guaranteed on all engines.

children.name: narwhal/fs-boot
children.doc:
Pure JavaScript implementations of file system path
manipulation.

This module depends on the non-CommonJS "narwhal/engine"
module, particularly for an "os" property that has the
words "windows" or "winnt" to distinguish Windows from
Unix file systems.

children.name: ROOT
children.doc:
* `/` on Unix
* `\` on Windows

children.name: SEPARATOR
children.doc:
* `/` on Unix
* `\` on Windows

children.name: ALT_SEPARATOR
children.doc:
* undefined on Unix
* `/` on Windows

children.name: split
children.doc:
separates a path into components.  If the path is
absolute, the first path component is the root of the
file system, indicated by an empty string on Unix, and a
drive letter followed by a colon on Windows.

children.name: join

returns.doc: path

children.doc:
Takes file system paths as variadic arguments and treats
each as a file or directory path and returns the path
arrived by traversing into the those paths.  All
arguments except for the last must be paths to
directories for the result to be meaningful.

children.name: resolve

returns.doc: path

children.doc:
Takes file system paths as variadic arguments and treats
each path as a location, in the URL sense, resolving each
new location based on the previous.  For example, if the
first argument is the absolute path of a JSON file, and
the second argument is a path mentioned in that JSON
file, `resolve` returns the absolute path of the
mentioned file.

children.name: normal

returns.doc: path

children.doc:
Takes paths as any number of arguments and reduces them
into a single path in normal form, removing all "." path
components, and reducing ".." path components by removing
the previous path component if possible.

returns.doc: whether the given path begins at the root of the file system or a drive letter.
whether the given path does not begin at the root of the file system or a drive letter.
whether the given path component corresponds to the root of the file system or a drive letter, as applicable.
the Unix root path or corresponding Windows drive for a given path.
the parent directory of the given path.

params.name: extention
params.doc: an optional extention to detect and remove if it exists.

returns.doc: the last component of a path, without the given extension if the extension is provided and matches the given file.
the extension (e.g., `txt`) of the file at the given path.

params.name: mode
params.doc: as String, options as Object, permissions as Number

params.name: mode
params.doc: as String, options as Object, permissions as Number

params.name: mode
params.doc: as String, options as Object, permissions as Number

children.name: narwhal/global-commonjs
children.doc:
Attempts to patch the existing free objects to bring the
context up to compliance with CommonJS specifications.

This module is required during Narwhal's bootstrapping so
that all modules.

children.name: narwhal/global-es5
children.doc:
Brings an environment as close to ECMAScript 5 compliance
as is possible with the facilities of erstwhile engines.

ES5 Draft
http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/drafts/tc39-2009-050.pdf

NOTE: this is a draft, and as such, the URL is subject to change.  If the
link is broken, check in the parent directory for the latest TC39 PDF.
http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/drafts/

Previous ES5 Draft
http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/drafts/tc39-2009-025.pdf
This is a broken link to the previous draft of ES5 on which most of the
numbered specification references and quotes herein were taken.  Updating
these references and quotes to reflect the new document would be a welcome
volunteer project.

children.name: narwhal/html
children.doc: Provides basic HTML string manipulation routines.

children.name: escape
children.doc: Escape significant HTML characters as HTML entities.

children.name: unescape
children.doc:
Translate basic HTML entities for ampersand, less-than,
and greater-than to their respective plain characters.

children.name: stripTags
children.doc: Strip HTML tags.

children.name: narwhal/ini
children.doc:
Provides methods for encoding and decoding Windows INI
configuration files.

returns.doc: decoded where the section key, `"-"` signifies the default sections.

params.name: unencoded
params.doc: where the section key, `"-"`, signifies the default section.  If a single section is provided, it is the default section.

returns.doc: encoded

children.name: narwhal/io-boot
children.doc: Provides building blocks for byte and character IO streams.

children.name: Reader
children.doc: Common traits of input streams.

children.name: read
children.doc:
routes `read` calls to `readAll`, `readBlock`, or
`readMax(n)` depending on whether the argument is
`undefined`, `null`, or a `Number` respectively.

children.name: readBlock
children.doc:
as a default implementation, calls `readMax` with no
argument.  This is intended to be overriden or replaced
if block size information is available.

returns.doc: the entirety of the remaining input.

children.name: copy
children.doc:
pumps data from this source input stream to the target output
stream.

returns.doc: the next chunk of input (from `read(null)`, or @throws `StopIteration` if the next chunk is empty.

children.name: iterator

returns.doc: this

children.doc:
A suitable implementation of `iterator` for any type that
is itself an iterator, not merely iterable.

children.name: IO
children.doc: Unifies an input and an output stream into a single API.

children.name: TextIO
children.doc: unifies a text input and output stream into a single API.

children.name: TextIOForMode
children.doc:
Wraps a raw byte stream with the appropriate text stream
for the given mode.

children.name: narwhal/loader
children.doc:
Provides a file-system-backed module loader
implementation, as used by Narwhal's bootstrapping, and
instantiable for nested module systems.

children.name: Loader
children.doc:
Creates a module loader for plain-text modules stored
on the local file system with the given options.

* `factories` is a pre-initialized map of top-level
  module identifiers to functions that accept a record of
  free variables to instantiate a module.
* `paths` is an `Array` of fully-qualified path `String`s
  wherein to search for top-level module identifiers
  in order.  Paths are sought in the outer loop, thus
  have lower precedence than extensions.
* `extensions` is an `Array` of extensions to search for,
  including the dot `.` if applicable, or an empty string
  to match all files.  The default is `["", ".js"]`.
  Extensions are sought in an inner loop, having higher
  precedence than paths.
* `debug` is whether to print debug messages.

In a module context, `require.loader` is or contains 
(as in a `MultiLoader` which can multiplex extensions to
alternate loaders) a `Loader` instance.

children.name: resolve

returns.doc: the corresponding top-level identifier.

children.doc:
Resolves module identifiers into the top-level,
or absolute module name space.

An alias to `resolve` as exported by this module.

children.name: resolvePkg

params.name: pkg
params.doc: a package reference, scoped to the current package.

returns.doc: the corresponding top-level identifier and package identifier.

children.doc:
Resolves a module identifier and package pair.

Forwards to the `resolvePkg` method of this module.

throws.doc: of no module can be found with the given top-level identifier.

returns.doc: factory a module factory ("maker") function.

params.name: path
params.doc: an optional hint about the path for the corresponding identifier, to spare having to find it again.

returns.doc: the text of the corresponding module file in the topmost module path with the first applicable extension.

params.name: topId
params.doc: the top-level identifier of the module corresponding to the given text, used to

params.name: path
params.doc: an optional hint for the file name of the module corresponding to the given text, used to produce helpful stack traces.

returns.doc: a module factory function or maker that executes the given text with the owned properties of the given `scope` record as free variables.  The returned function may have a `path` property to provide hints to the recipient for debugging.

params.name: path
params.doc: an optional path to provide a hint about where to find the text corresponding to the given topId, provided merely to avoid recomputation.

returns.doc: the memoized module factory function corresponding to the given top-level identifier.

children.name: reload

params.name: path
params.doc: an optional path to provide a hint about where to find the text corresponding to the given topId, provided merely to avoid recomputation.

children.doc:
Forces a module to be reloaded, setting or replacing
the module factory function in the module factory
memo.  This function is called by `load` internally
to populate the memo and may be called externally
to freshen the memo.

returns.doc: whether a module factory function has already been loaded for the given identifier.

params.name: path
params.doc: a hint on the whereabouts of the given module.

children.name: resolve

returns.doc: the corresponding top-level identifier.

children.doc:
Resolves module identifiers into the top-level,
or absolute module name space.

children.name: narwhal/logger
children.doc:
Provides basic logging, and logging types instantiable
for alternate output streams.

children.name: narwhal/md4
children.doc:
A JavaScript implementation of the RSA Data Security, Inc. MD4 Message
Digest Algorithm, as defined in RFC 1320.

returns.doc: a hexadecimal string of the MD4 hash for a given string, as interpreted in bytes.

children.name: narwhal/mime
children.doc:
This module provides basic functions for handling mime-types. It can
handle matching mime-types against a list of media-ranges. See section
14.1 of the HTTP specification [RFC 2616] for a complete explanation.

  <http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.1>

A port to JavaScript of Joe Gregorio's MIME-Type Parser:

  <http://code.google.com/p/mimeparse/>

Ported by J. Chris Anderson <jchris@apache.org>, targeting the Spidermonkey runtime.

To run the tests, open mimeparse-js-test.html in a browser.
Ported from version 0.1.2.
Comments are mostly excerpted from the original.

children.name: parseMimeType
children.doc:
Carves up a mime-type and returns an Array of the
[type, subtype, params] where "params" is a Hash of all
the parameters for the media range.

For example, the media range "application/xhtml;q=0.5" would
get parsed into:

    ["application", "xhtml", { "q" : "0.5" }]

children.name: fitnessAndQualityParsed

params.name: mimeType
params.doc: as from an HTTP Content-Type header.

params.name: parsedRanges
params.doc: as from an HTTP Accept header and processed with `parseMediaRange`.

children.doc:
Find the best match for a given mime-type against
a list of media_ranges that have already been
parsed by parseMediaRange(). Returns an array of
the fitness value and the value of the 'q' quality
parameter of the best match, or (-1, 0) if no match
was found. Just as for qualityParsed(), 'parsed_ranges'
must be a list of parsed media ranges.

children.name: qualityParsed
children.doc:
Find the best match for a given mime-type against
a list of media_ranges that have already been
parsed by parseMediaRange(). Returns the
'q' quality parameter of the best match, 0 if no
match was found. This function bahaves the same as quality()
except that 'parsedRanges' must be a list of
parsed media ranges.

children.name: quality

params.name: mimeType
params.doc: as from an HTTP Content-Type header

params.name: ranges
params.doc: as from an HTTP Accept header

children.doc:
Returns the quality 'q' of a mime-type when compared
against the media-ranges in ranges. For example::

    js> MIME.quality('text/html','text/*;q=0.3, text/html;q=0.7, text/html;level=1, text/html;level=2;q=0.4, *\/*;q=0.5')
    0.7

children.name: bestMatch
children.doc:
Takes a list of supported mime-types and finds the best
match for all the media-ranges listed in header. The value of
header must be a string that conforms to the format of the
HTTP Accept: header. The value of 'supported' is a list of
mime-types::

    js> MIME.bestMatch(['application/xbel+xml', 'text/xml'], 'text/*;q=0.5,*\/*; q=0.1')
    "text/xml"

children.name: narwhal/os
children.doc:
Provides operating system call support, particularly POSIX calls
when possible.

children.name: system

params.name: command
params.doc: uses "/bin/sh -c" if the command is a string.

returns.doc: Number exit status

children.doc:
executes a given command, attached to this process's
IO streams, and returns the exit status.

children.name: exec

throws.doc: if execution resumes with the old program image.

children.doc:
Supported in Rhino and Node.  On Rhino, acceptance of the command
object and the search argument are not yet supported.

children.name: exec0

params.name: search
params.doc: optionally whether to use the `env.PATH` to search for `command`

children.doc:
Strictly built on Posix `execv`, `execvp`, and `execvP`,
where the command is provided as the first argument and 
args[0] is the original path used to execute the command.

children.name: status

params.name: command
params.doc: uses "/bin/sh -c" if the command is a string.

returns.doc: Number exit status

children.doc:
executes a given command quietly and returns
the exit status.

children.name: command

params.name: command
params.doc: uses "/bin/sh -c" if the command is a string.

returns.doc: String the standard output of the command

children.doc:
executes a given command and returns the
standard output.  If the exit status is non-zero,
throws an Error.

children.name: enquote
children.doc:
enquotes a string such that it is guaranteed to be a single
argument with no interpolated values for a shell.

WARNING: as yet, this implementation only handles
enquoting for Unix shell script style arguments.  Further
development is necessary to enquote and escape arguments
on Windows.

children.name: parse

params.name: command
params.doc: {String} a command composed of space delimited, quoted, or backslash escaped arguments.

returns.doc: an Array of unquoted arguments.

children.doc:
parses command line arguments

WARNING: this does not handle all of the edge cases
of command line argument parsing, nor is suitable for
general purpose argument enquoting on all platforms.  It
also will never be able to handle environment variable
interpolation or other forms of shell quote expansion.
This utility is used by Narwhal to pare arguments from
system.env.NARWHAL_OPT.

params.name: paths
params.doc: a variadic list of path terms.

returns.doc: an array of all files that match the given paths in every package.  Each of the variadic path terms may be replaced with their configured equivalents in their respective package, as described by the `directories` property in the given package's `package.json` file.

params.name: paths
params.doc: variadically, for a path in any overlayed package.  Packages complying to the CommonJS Packages/1.0 specification may have a `package.json` file with a `directories` property.  Each variadic term in the path that corresponds to one of the remapped directory names will get replaced with the corresponding value in each respective package.

returns.doc: a path object from `narwhal/fs` in the `narwhal-lib` package for the file in the first package that contains a corresponding path, or `undefined` if no matching file exists.  If the paths correspond to an absolute path, returns that as a path object.  @throws {Error} an error if no corresponding path exists.

params.name: paths
params.doc: variadically, for a path in any overlayed package. Packages complying to the CommonJS Packages/1.0 specification may have a `package.json` file with a `directories` property.  Each variadic term in the path that corresponds to one of the remapped directory names will get replaced with the corresponding value in each respective package.

throws.doc: an error if no corresponding path exists.

returns.doc: a path object from `narwhal/fs` in the `narwhal-lib` package for the file in the first package that contains a corresponding path.  If the paths correspond to an absolute path, returns that as a path object.

children.name: main
children.doc:
Finds, reads, and analyzes overlayed packages then
applies those findings to the module loader and memoizes
the results as properties of this module.  This involves
a breadth-first- search for packages and packages within
packages, and performing engine-specific configuration.

children.name: usingCatalog
children.doc: Set by `main`.

children.name: order
children.doc:
an array of the same packages in the
`catalog` in order from most to least dependent, so that
you are guaranteed that, if a package depends on another,
it appears before it in `order`.

children.name: root
children.doc: the active package.

children.name: catalog
children.doc:
A mapping of engine package names to engine package objects,
for all installed engine packages.

children.name: read
children.doc:
read
recursively loads all package data from package.json files
and packages/ directories.

children.name: verify
children.doc:
scans a package object for missing dependencies and
throws away any package that has unmet dependencies.

children.name: sortedPackages
children.doc:
sortedPackages
returns an array of packages in order from the most
dependent to least dependent, sorted based on
their transitive dependencies.

children.name: analyze
children.doc:
analyze
constructs prioritized top-level module paths
based on the given sorted package array.

children.name: synthesize
children.doc:
synthesize
applies the results of the analysis on the current
execution environment.

children.name: addJsPaths
children.doc: addJsPaths

children.name: normalize
children.doc:
normalize
normalizes all of the packages in a catalog

children.name: normalizePackage
children.doc: normalizePackage

children.name: Package
children.doc: A package descriptor.

params.name: path
params.doc: components.  Each term may be replaced if a corresponding entry exists in the package's `package.json` package descriptor's `directories` property.

returns.doc: a path in the package, regardless of whether a corresponding file exists.
a string like `Author Name (http://example.com/) <author@example.com>`, where each component is optional.

children.name: regexp
children.doc:
A regular expression that matches against author strings
like `Author Name (http://example.com/) <author@example.com>`,
where each component is optional.

children.name: Version

returns.doc: a normalized version

children.doc:
Normalizes `undefined` to an empty `Array`.
Normalizes a `String` to an `Array` of `String`s.
All other values are returned unaltered.

provides printf and sprintf.

This code is unrestricted: you are free to use it however you like.

The functions should work as expected, performing left or right alignment,
truncating strings, outputting numbers with a required precision etc.

For complex cases, these functions follow the Perl implementations of
(s)printf, allowing arguments to be passed out-of-order, and to set the
precision or length of the output based on arguments instead of fixed
numbers.

See http://perldoc.perl.org/functions/sprintf.html for more information.

Implemented:

* zero and space-padding
* right and left-alignment,
* base X prefix (binary, octal and hex)
* positive number prefix
* (minimum) width
* precision / truncation / maximum width
* out of order arguments

Not implemented (yet):

* vector flag
* size (bytes, words, long-words etc.)

Will not implement:

* %n or %p (no pointers in JavaScript)

by Ash Searle, 2007-04-27
Integrated into Chiron by Kris Kowal, 2007-10-19
Integrated into Narwhal by Kris Kowal, 2009-07-27

children.name: printf
children.doc:
Writes a formatted string to standard output, as
forwarded from `print` to `SYSTEM.print` to
`SYSTEM.stdout.print` or intercepted anywhere along that
chain.

children.name: fprintf
children.doc: Prints a formatted string to a given stream.

returns.doc: a promise for `undefined` that will resolve after `timeout` miliseconds.
a promise for an array of each resolved value respectively.

params.name: values
params.doc: a promise for an array of promises.

returns.doc: a promise for the sum of the resolved.

children.name: whenAll
children.doc: Wraps a `when` block

params.name: thisp
params.doc: optional this object for the callback

returns.doc: an array of promises for the returned results of the callback on each respective resolved value.

params.name: thisp
params.doc: optional this object for the callback

returns.doc: a promise for an array of the returned results of the callback on each respective resolved value.

children.name: Queue
children.doc:
A promise queue.  Each promise returned by get is
eventually resolved by a value given to put, in the order
in which they are requested and received.

returns.doc: a promise

children.name: narwhal/promise
children.doc:
Provides a robust API for interacting with functions that
can neither block execution nor resolve a return value
immediately.  Such functions may return promises if they
find that they must perform a long latency operation in
their transitive function call tree, and will eventually
resolve or reject thir returned promise with a value or
a reason for failure.  These resolutions and rejections
can be observed and composed with other promises, and
rejections percolate in a manner analogous to `try`, 
`catch`, and `finally`.

In addition, this module provides facilities that permit
interactions to be requested on the eventually resolved
value of a promise and forwarded along a pipeline to
reduce chattiness.  This permits high-performance,
object-granular interaction with distant processes.

This implementation is a prototype conforming to the
alternate promise proposal for CommonJS:
http://wiki.commonjs.org/wiki/Promises/B

This implementation and the specification are based on
Tyler Close's `ref_send.js`.

children.name: enqueue
children.doc: Performs a task in a future turn of the event loop.

children.name: defer
children.doc:
Constructs a {promise, resolve} object.

The resolver is a callback to invoke with a more resolved value for the
promise. To fulfill the promise, invoke the resolver with any value that is
not a function. To reject the promise, invoke the resolver with a rejection
object. To put the promise in the same state as another promise, invoke the
resolver with that other promise.

children.name: Promise
children.doc:
Constructs a Promise with a promise descriptor object and optional fallback
function.  The descriptor contains methods like when(rejected), get(name),
put(name, value), post(name, args), delete(name), and valueOf(), which all
return either a value, a promise for a value, or a rejection.  The fallback
accepts the operation name, a resolver, and any further arguments that would
have been forwarded to the appropriate method above had a method been
provided with the proper name.  The API makes no guarantees about the nature
of the returned object, apart from that it is usable whereever promises are
bought and sold.

returns.doc: whether the given object is a promise. Otherwise it is a resolved value.

children.name: reject
children.doc: Constructs a rejected promise.

children.name: ref
children.doc: Constructs a promise for an immediate reference.

children.name: Method
children.doc:
Constructs a promise method that can be used to safely observe resolution of
a promise for an arbitrarily named method like "propfind" in a future turn.

"Method" constructs methods like "get(promise, name)" and "put(promise)".

children.name: when

params.name: value
params.doc: promise or immediate reference to observe

params.name: resolve
params.doc: function to be called with the resolved value

params.name: rejected
params.doc: function to be called with the rejection reason

returns.doc: promise for the return value from the invoked callback

children.doc:
Registers an observer on a promise.

Guarantees:

1. that resolved and rejected will be called only once.
2. that either the resolved callback or the rejected callback will be
   called, but not both.
3. that resolved and rejected will not be called in this turn.

children.name: get

params.name: object
params.doc: promise or immediate reference for target object

returns.doc: promise for the property value

children.doc: Gets the value of a property in a future turn.

children.name: put

params.name: object
params.doc: promise or immediate reference for object object

returns.doc: promise for the return value

children.doc: Sets the value of a property in a future turn.

children.name: del

params.name: object
params.doc: promise or immediate reference for target object

returns.doc: promise for the return value

children.doc: Deletes a property in a future turn.

children.name: post

params.name: object
params.doc: promise or immediate reference for target object

returns.doc: promise for the return value

children.doc: Invokes a method in a future turn.

children.name: defined
children.doc: Guarantees that the give promise resolves to a defined, non-null value.

children.name: narwhal/querystring

Objects with cyclic references trigger an exception.

children.name: Sandbox
children.doc:
Creates a `require` function, and arranges for modules
to be executed and their exports memoized, in a lexical
scope that includes:

* `require(id)` with support for identifiers relative to
  the calling module.
* `require.loader` for direct access to the module
   loader, which can be used in nested sandboxes.
* `require.force(id)`
* `require.once(id, scope)` to execute but not memoize
  a module, with an optional object that owns additional
  free variables to inject into the module's lexical
  scope.
* `module`
  * `id`
  * `path`
* `exports`

children.name: sandbox

params.name: main
params.doc: a top-level identifier for the main module to execute in the sandbox.

children.doc:
Creates a sandbox and executes a main module in the
sandbox.

A JavaScript implementation of the Secure Hash Algorithm, SHA-1, as defined
in FIPS PUB 180-1

Version 2.1a Copyright Paul Johnston 2000 - 2002.

Other contributors: Greg Holt, Andrew Kepert, Ydnar, Lostinet

Distributed under the BSD License

See http://pajhome.org.uk/crypt/md5 for details.

Ported to Chiron and Narwhal by Kris Kowal

`alphabet16Lower` is the default hexadecimal alphabet.

and function level.

children.doc:
base-64 pad character. "=" for strict RFC compliance, "" for brevity
"=" by default.
This value can be overridden on the module
and function level.

children.name: characterSize
children.doc:
bits per input character. 8 - ASCII; 16 - Unicode
This value can be overridden on the module
and function level.

children.name: ord
children.doc:
Returns the character code ordinal (offset in the ASCII or Unicode tables)
for a given single character. 

* inverse: `chr`

children.name: chr
children.doc:
Returns the character for a given character code ordinal (offset in the
ASCII or Unicode tables).

* inverse: `ord`

children.name: narwhal/term
children.doc:
Provides an output stream interface that translates
readable null-prefix codes into VT-100 escape sequences,
managing independent text formatting stacks for
foreground, background, and weight, and coordinating
output so that command sequences are not interpolated
in the data sent to standard output, preserving its
format so that it may be pipelined.

children.name: Stream
children.doc:
Constructs a terminal output stream that translates
literate color encodings like "\0blue(I'm blue\0)" into
VT-100 escape sequences, maintaining independent stacks
for foreground, background, and font weight so terminal
settings are restored when they are out of scope.

Escape sequences are channeled to the `stderr` channel to
preserve the consistency of the data written to `stdout`,
such that it can be safely pipelined.  The translating
functions coordinate flushing of `stdout` and `stderr`
to ensure that formatting is applied correctly.

children.name: writeCode
children.doc:
Writes and flushes a VT-100 escape sequence to the
error stream if the stream is enabled, coordinating
the flushing of output and errput to guarantee that
colors are interleaved properly.

children.name: print
children.doc:
Prints a line of space separated fields, translating
any encountered null-tokens to VT-100 sequences,
coordinating standard input and output.

children.name: printError
children.doc:
Prints a line of space separated fields to standard
error.

children.name: write

params.name: toError
params.doc: (optional) dictates that the string should be shunted to standard error instead of out.

children.doc:
Writes a string, tranlating null-prefix-codes to VT-100
codes.

params.name: fore
params.doc: a VT-100, single-digit color code for the foreground color.

params.name: back
params.doc: a VT-100, signle-digit color code for the background color.

children.name: error
children.doc:
A subset of the output stream API that forwards
`print` and `write` to the translator's underlying
standard error.

children.name: stream
children.doc:
A singleton instance of `Stream` for the current module
sandbox, using the `system` module.

children.name: TLDS

children.name: narwhal/util
children.doc: The missing methods.

children.name: operator
children.doc:
a decorator for functions that curry "polymorphically",
that is, that return a function that can be tested
against various objects if they're only "partially
completed", or fewer arguments than needed are used.

this enables the idioms:

    [1, 2, 3].every(lt(4)) eq true
    [1, 2, 3].map(add(1)) eq [2, 3, 4]
    [{}, {}, {}].forEach(set('a', 10))

returns.doc: whether the value is null or undefined

params.name: object
params.doc: an object of various types that may be converted to a record object.  Objects with `toObject` methods are coerced using that method.  "lengthable" objects are converted to key, value pairs with `items` and converted to objects with the corresponding properties.  Other objects are shallowly copied on their owned properties.

returns.doc: a shallow copy on all owned properties
a deep copy on all owned properties

children.name: update

returns.doc: updated object

children.doc:
Updates an object with the properties from another object.
This function is variadic requiring a minimum of two arguments.
The first argument is the object to update.  Remaining arguments
are considered the sources for the update.  If multiple sources
contain values for the same property, the last one with that
property in the arguments list wins.

example usage:

    util.update({}, { hello: "world" });  // -> { hello: "world" }
    util.update({}, { hello: "world" }, { hello: "le monde" }); // -> { hello: "le monde" }

children.name: complete

returns.doc: completed object

children.name: by
children.doc:
returns a `comparator` that compares
values based on the values resultant from
a given `relation`.
accepts a `relation` and an optional comparator.

To sort a list of objects based on their
"a" key:

    objects.sort(by(get("a")))

To get those in descending order:

    objects.sort(by(get("a")), desc)

`by` returns a comparison function that also tracks
the arguments you used to construct it.  This permits
`sort` and `sorted` to perform a Schwartzian transform
which can increase the performance of the sort
by a factor of 2.

children.name: sort
children.doc:
sort
an in-place array sorter that uses a deep comparison
function by default (compare), and improves performance if
you provide a comparator returned by "by", using a
Schwartzian transform.

children.name: sorted
children.doc:
sorted
returns a sorted copy of an array using a deep
comparison function by default (compare), and
improves performance if you provide a comparator
returned by "by", using a Schwartzian transform.

children.name: escape
children.doc:
escapes all characters of a string that are
special to JavaScript and many other languages.
Recognizes all of the relevant
control characters and formats all other
non-printable characters as Hex byte escape
sequences or Unicode escape sequences depending
on their size.

Pass `true` as an optional second argument and
`escape` produces valid contents for escaped
JSON strings, wherein non-printable-characters are
all escaped with the Unicode `\u` notation.

children.name: enquote
children.doc:
transforms a string into a string literal, escaping
all characters of a string that are special to
JavaScript and and some other languages.

`enquote` uses double quotes to be JSON compatible.

Pass `true` as an optional second argument to
be strictly JSON compliant, wherein all
non-printable-characters are represented with
Unicode escape sequences.

children.name: expand
children.doc: transforms tabs to an equivalent number of spaces.

params.name: a
params.doc: minimum length of the resultant `String`: by default, 2

returns.doc: the value padded up to at least the minimum length.  adds the padding to the begining side of the `String`.

params.name: length
params.doc: a minimum length of the resultant `String`, by default, 2

returns.doc: the value padded up to at least the minimum length.  adds the padding to the end side of the `String`.

children.name: splitName
children.doc:
splits a string into an array of words from an original
string.

children.name: joinName
children.doc:
joins a list of words with a given delimiter
between alphanumeric words.

children.name: upper
children.doc:
converts a name to `UPPER CASE` using
a given delimiter between numeric words.

children.name: lower
children.doc:
converts a name to a `lower case` using
a given delimiter between numeric words.

children.name: camel
children.doc:
converts a name to `camel Case` using
a given delimiter between numeric words.

children.name: title
children.doc:
converts a name to `Title Case` using
a given delimiter between numeric words.

children.name: narwhal/uuid
children.doc: Utilities for generating Universally Unique Identifiers.

children.name: uuid

params.name: radix
params.doc: (optional) the number of allowable values for each character.

children.doc:
Generate a random uuid.

EXAMPLES:

    // No arguments  - returns RFC4122, version 4 ID
    js> Math.uuid()
    "92329D39-6F5C-4520-ABFC-AAB64544E172"
    
    // One argument - returns ID of the specified length
    js> Math.uuid(15)     // 15 character ID (default base=62)
    "VcydxgltxrVZSTV"

    // Two arguments - returns ID of the specified length, and radix. (Radix must be <= 62)
    js> Math.uuid(8, 2)  // 8 character ID (base=2)
    "01001010"
    js> Math.uuid(8, 10) // 8 character ID (base=10)
    "47473046"
    js> Math.uuid(8, 16) // 8 character ID (base=16)
    "098F4D35"

children.name: narwhal/loader/multi
children.doc:
Provides a loader that can multiplex multiple loaders
based on the extension of the found file name.

children.name: MultiLoader
children.doc:
Constructs a MultiLoader object for loading modules
from various file formats, based on their extension.

Options include:

* `paths` array of fully-qualified paths to search
  for top-level modules
* `loaders` an array of tuples, mapping extensions
  to loader objects supporting:
  * `load(id, path)`
  * `reload(id, path)`
  * `hasChanged(id)` optionally
* `loader` used to create a default `loaders`, mapping
  both `".js"` and arbitrary other files to that loader,
  itself defaulting to a file-system backed loader
  constructed with the same options.
* `debug` and other options are forwarded to the
  constructor of `Loader` if no loaders are specified.

children.name: paths
children.doc: May be modified in-place but not replaced.

children.name: loader
children.doc: May be modified in-place but not replaced.

children.name: loaders
children.doc: May be modified in-place but not replaced.

children.name: resolve

returns.doc: the corresponding top-level identifier.

children.doc:
Resolves module identifiers into the top-level,
or absolute module name space.

An alias to `resolve` as exported by the `loader`
module.

children.name: resolvePkg

params.name: pkg
params.doc: a package reference, scoped to the current package.

returns.doc: the corresponding top-level identifier and package identifier.

children.doc:
Resolves a module identifier and package pair.

Forwards to the `resolvePkg` method of the `loader`
module.

throws.doc: of no module can be found with the given top-level identifier.

returns.doc: factory a module factory ("maker") function.

params.name: path
params.doc: an optional path to provide a hint about where to find the text corresponding to the given topId, provided merely to avoid recomputation.

returns.doc: the memoized module factory function corresponding to the given top-level identifier.

children.name: reload

params.name: path
params.doc: an optional path to provide a hint about where to find the text corresponding to the given topId, provided merely to avoid recomputation.

children.doc:
Forces a module to be reloaded, if possible, setting
or replacing the module factory function in the
module factory memo.  This function is called by
`load` internally to populate the memo and may be
called externally to freshen the memo.

returns.doc: whether a module factory function has already been loaded for the given identifier.

children.name: events
Event
children.doc:
An activation object for event observers that permits an observer to affect
whether the an event continues to propagate to other observers and whether
the emitting signal completes its default action.

children.name: stop
children.doc:
prevents further propagation and the default action of the emitting
signal.

children.name: stopPropagation
children.doc: prevents further propagation of the emitting signal

children.name: cancelDefault
children.doc: prevents the default action of the emitting signal.

returns.doc: whether this event instructs the emitting signal to continue propagating to further observers.
whether this event instructs the emitting signal to apply its default action.

children.name: Signal
children.doc:
Signal
base prototype for a signal that emits events.

children.name: addListener

params.name: observer
params.doc: {Function} a function to call when this signal is emitted.  All observers get called before the signal's "default action", if it has one.  Observers are called on a first-come, first-served basis.

params.name: Event
params.doc: {Event type} an optional Event type to be used for the returned Signal that defaults to Event.

returns.doc: a Signal that is emitted before the given observer.

children.doc:
arranges for a given observer function to be called whenever
this signal is emitted.  The calling of this observer
function can in turn be observed by the returned signal.

children.name: emit
children.doc:
emits an event with to all observers and the signal's default action, by
applying each function with the event instance as the activation object
and the forwarding the given arguments.  Uses the event object to
determine whether to continue propagating from observer to the next, and
whether to apply the default action.

children.name: observer

returns.doc: a function that, when called with arbitrary arguments, arranges for the signal to be observed with a given function that receives those arguments.
a function that emits this signal when it is called.
all observer functions in order.  Modifications to the returned array will not affect the behavior of the signal.

children.name: EventEmitter
children.doc:
Emitter
base prototype for objects with observable, named, event signals.

children.name: emit

params.name: name
params.doc: {String} the name of the signal to emit.

children.doc:
emits an event to all observers of signal with a particular name.
Further arguments are applied to each observer.

children.name: addListener

params.name: name
params.doc: {String} the name of the signal to observe.

children.doc: adds an observer to this object's signal for a given name.

children.name: removeListener
children.doc: removes an observer from this object's signal for a given name.

children.name: setSignal

params.name: name
params.doc: {String} the name of the signal slot.  Only one signal can be created for each name.

params.name: signal
params.doc: an optional function or Signal object

params.name: Event
params.doc: an optional event type that will be instantiated and passed as the activation object to each observer each time the signal emits an event.

returns.doc: a signal, albeit one wrapped around the given function.

children.doc: adds a Signal slot to this event emitter with a given name.

children.name: getSignal

params.name: name
params.doc: {String} name of the signal to get.

children.doc:
returns the Signal for a given name.  Throws an error if
no signal has been slotted by the given name.

returns.doc: whether a Signal has been registered for the given name.

children.name: Observable
children.doc:
Observable < Emitter
a mixin type for any object that can emit events when certain property
functions are called.

children.name: setSignalRaw
children.doc:
sets a signal using the Emitter system, bypassing the Observable's
setSignal behavior of adding the emitter as a property of the instance.

children.name: setSignal
children.doc:
adds a signal slot for the given name and sets it to a property of the
activation object (this).  This property function should only be called
during the process of constructing this instance.

children.name: Deferred
children.doc:
a type of Deferred that corresponds to the future state of a
value, including both the promise of for that value to be
resolved, and a resolver which provides the means to advance the
progress of the promise on its way to resolution.

children.name: emit
children.doc:
a Deferred's promise differs from a normal event Emitter
because it has two states: "waiting" and "resolved".  When
the promise is waiting, all event emissions are queued.  When
the promise is either resolved or rejected, all of those
events are emitted.  All subsequent emissions are sent
immediately.

returns.doc: either a promise or the resolved value for the promise.

children.name: emitSuccess
children.doc: resolves the promise or defers it further with a new promise.

children.name: reject
children.doc:
rejects the promise by resolving it with a Rejection with 
a given "reason"

children.name: when
children.doc:
forwards the "when" message to the contained promise to
emulate the promise API.

children.name: progress
children.doc:
a signal that can be called to set the progress state
of the deferrence to a number between 0 and 1, or can
be observed with the "observe" method.

returns.doc: the progress of the deferred or undefined if that is unknown. User interface widgets should take "undefined" as a queue to display indefinite progress.

children.name: ok
children.doc:
a signal that can be observed but not explicitly emitted for when the
promise is fully resolved.

children.name: error
children.doc:
a signal that can be observed but not explicitly emitted for when the
promise is rejected.

children.name: cancel
children.doc: a signal that rejects the promise and notifies any observers.

params.name: time
params.doc: {Number} in miliseconds, at which point the corresponding promise will be rejected if it has not been resolved.

children.name: Promise
children.doc:
An object that represents a promise to provide a value eventually.  When
this value is provided or fails to be provided can be observed using
"Q.when(promise, ok, error, progress)".

children.name: wait
children.doc:
blocks until this promise has been resolved or rejected, if the
underlying engine supports blocking promises.

children.name: prototype
children.doc:
a signal that rejects this promise with a cancellation error, or the
given error and notifies all observers.  Observers are afforded an
opportunity to prevent cancellation through their event object.

children.name: noSuchMethod
children.doc: rejects Promise API calls that are not supported by this type of promise.

children.name: Rejection
children.doc:
A type of Promise that represents rejection of a promise for some given
reason.

children.name: Reference
children.doc: A type of Promise that represents a value on its way to resolution.

children.name: defer
children.doc:
returns a Deferred.  A future is an Emitter and contains
a promise and its corresponding resolver.

children.name: promise
children.doc:
given any value, a reference promise, a resolved promise, or a
rejected promise, return a promise.  If the given object is not a
promise, it will be wrapped as a reference promise.

children.name: isPromise

returns.doc: whether the given object is a promise.

children.doc:
returns whether a given object is recognized
as a promise.  Presently, this amounts to duck-typing
on the presence of a "then" property function, but
could conceivably be done by checking whether the object
is an instance of Promise.

children.name: ref
children.doc: returns a Reference.

children.name: valueOf
children.doc:
given any value, a reference promise, a resolved promise, or a
rejected promise, attempt to return the most resolved form of the
value.  If the promise is resolved, this will be a non-promise
object.

children.name: reject
children.doc: returns a Rejection

children.name: when

params.name: resolvedCallback

params.name: rejectCallback
params.doc: function to be called with the rejection reason

params.name: progressCallback
params.doc: function to be called when progress is made

returns.doc: promise for the return value from the invoked callback or the value if it is a non-promise value

children.doc: Registers an observer on a promise.

children.name: whenPromise

params.name: resolvedCallback
params.doc: function to be called with the resolved value

params.name: rejectCallback
params.doc: function to be called with the rejection reason

params.name: progressCallback
params.doc: function to be called when progress is made

returns.doc: promise for the return value from the invoked callback

children.doc: Registers an observer on a promise.

children.name: get

params.name: target
params.doc: promise or value for target object

returns.doc: promise for the property value

children.doc: Gets the value of a property in a future turn.

children.name: put

params.name: target
params.doc: promise or value for target object

returns.doc: promise for the return value

children.doc: Sets the value of a property in a future turn.

children.name: post

params.name: target
params.doc: promise or value for target object

returns.doc: promise for the return value

children.doc: Invokes a method in a future turn.

children.name: wait

params.name: object
params.doc: promise or value to wait for

returns.doc: the value of the promise

children.doc:
Waits for the given promise to finish, blocking (and executing
other events) if necessary to wait for the promise to finish. If
target is not a promise it will return the target immediately. If
the promise results in an rejection, that rejection will be
thrown.
